div.ab: O feeble ones, why weep ye, over your dead: who in death are at rest from sorrows and sins?
Response: Glory to Him Who endured all, for the sake of all men: yea tasted death for the sake of all, to bring all to life
I reveal unto you, that even Satan, though much content: at your weeping, yet laughs much, at your mourning.
In mockery he winks at me and nods to me, as a jester: Come let us laugh at sinners, for lo! they are mad.
Truly they have given up remembrance of that fire, which I have hidden for them: and lo! the fools are drunken with weeping, for their departed.
Instead of weeping as though, without provision: I had plundered and sent forth their dead, lo! they are mad.
The souls of the evil are to be afflicted, till the judgment day: and these weep over the graves, like to madmen.
They care not for their own sins, that haply to-morrow: they must go in shame of face, to join their dead.
And thus shall all be put to shame alike, family by family: in Sheol the wretches shall repent without avail.
Leave the drunken and the madman, until that day: wherein each shall shake off his wine wherewith he was maddened.
I will go to gather them, like children: that they may play the wanton and the madman, until they perish.
Lo! I have revealed to you the mystery, the secret of my comrade: go forth therefore, depart, amend, in repentance.
Leave me, I too will depart, I will see to my affairs: that with open face I may give my account to my Lord.
I know that the wind as it blew, has borne away my words: for ye are the same whom I, ofttimes have proved.
I remember Jeremiah how he, compared boldness: to the Indian who changes not his skin, though it is of freedom.
For this too belongs to it, even to freedom: that it binds itself by the will, as though by nature.
For so powerful is the will, in them that are free: that it may be likened to nature, through its workings.

noteGrp.note: I.e. though boldness is matter of free will, it becomes a second nature.
